instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>.
Missing:
-<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>
-<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> & apwrok
-<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

-<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> .018
-<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> .035
-<SIGNAL>PCH_PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> .014

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> .015

Have I been paying good attention with where I am going?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Need basics first, PPBUS, 3V3 on L7560. Is there a short pulse on L7520 after connecting power? Where was liquid damage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: L7560 3.3v. No pulse and nothing on L7520, liquid yes.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Good morning : ) you guys are up early over there!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
No Title

It is prehistoric but it (L7520) stays flat 0 when I first plug it in and stays that way.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Little bit of liquid was near clock, <CHIP>U1845</CHIP> (changed), <CAPACITOR>C1020</CAPACITOR> (short to ground or low resistance to ground? .007). Everything else is pretty clean.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: If there was liquid on clock chip change it <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. Or if you want to measure check 32kHz on pin 12 and 3V on pin 13.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is good if I have 3.4 on pin 13 & pin 12 has a signal? I have both.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Did you check 32kHz with the scope?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Yes. I have an old school one though. It only shows that there is a signal, but it doesn't show the kHz.

threads.message: Why? Any scope will do for this. Most scoped have a 1kHz reference output, see if you can get that on the screen.

threads.message:
I'm not too sure on how to calculate this correctly. But I got 3.25 divisions per cycle at 5ms.
I don't see a 1kHz reference output.

threads.message: No need to calculate anything, are you seeing a sort of square wave form?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Voltages on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>-3. What is resistance to GND on <CAPACITOR>C1020</CAPACITOR> in Ohm?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
I read some previous posts and tried to help myself before I posted my question and already checked the <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>'s. I've gone over some of these things so many times I am getting to have them memorized : ) But here is what I have:
<RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> (3.3) on both
<RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>-1 (3.3) <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>-2 (3.0)
<RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR>-1 (3.3) <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR>-2 (3.2)
<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR>-1 (3.3) on both

<CAPACITOR>C1020</CAPACITOR> Red to ground diode mode = 0.008
<CAPACITOR>C1020</CAPACITOR> Black to ground Ohm = 16.7

So short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: >>> Louis ! - Do you have a video on measurements in resistance to ground in Ohms? If so, which video do you discuss this? I don't recall seeing one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: 16.7 is fine on that bus. Some people have reported that these boards do not start without a good battery connected. I have not really run into that, but it could be a possible issue here.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
Duke, thank you !
You can close this bad boy out !
This took so long the customer gave up hope, so I bought it off them so I can fix it.  I don't even want it, I hate Apple.  I just wanted to fix it : )
I want to know more about the last part of diagnosing (the 16.7 Ohm) whats this called or what were we checking for so I can find out more about it?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
The backlight just went out, but I think I can fix that pretty easy. 
: )

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: So was it a bad battery? What voltage do you get on the backlight output?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
No. The battery was actually good. This board came in a long time ago with minor water damage so I can't recall all that I did, very little though. The <CHIP>U1845</CHIP> I broke everyone I had off of donor boards. When the <CHIP>U1845</CHIP> came in the mail I put it on and couldn't figure anything out. (I will make a mental note about the battery being attached for testing!). When I first plugged the battery in I got the battery charging symbol bright and clear. I waited awhile and tried to turn on but kept saying charging. Then I though the fan has to be connected, so I disconnected the battery and put the fan on and it started right up. I only let it stay on for a few seconds into the Apple logo.

Once I put it together and turned it on again it was dim, I was able to see the login part dimmly.  So I thought it was backlight. But now I get no image -hahahaha !!!

I'm kinda glad because now I'll get to explore the image circuitry because I could never figure those out on my previous run-ins with no image. Backlight I've solved a few, but they were easy.

I'll do my research off other posts, & Louis's videos and see if I can solve this puzzle on my own : ) You'll probably be hearing back from me, LOL.

I do get the dong and seen it working, so my hopes are high. It's not a rush job or anything.

Question: Do I have to have the fan, battery and screen connected for testing around? Or just the battery and screen?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Yes. Battery has to be connected I am learning !

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Fan is not needed and will not even spin up on these before they get hot.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: Rodger that.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
Ok, so no enables on <CHIP>U8330</CHIP>, only the VCC.  All of those come from the <CHIP>U0500</CHIP>.
The GPU went out on me?  
It was fucking working before...  Uggg.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
Checked with flash light. There is no image.

At first there was a fully bright working screen with image, then the backlight went out, then the image went out. Still dongs.  I need to test with a good know screen first I imagine and external monitor.  I will be trying these things next opportunity.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: There is no corrosion near the the connector.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message:
I don't understand how a good screen could work and then not work. I don't see any damage to cable or connector. I do work with the battery disconnected of course. I've changed many of bare LCD's without issues and many lids also.  Never seen one up and die like this.  There was no liquid around this area. But I put in a new screen and now is all good : ) 
Thanks Duke : )

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S4
threads.message: I'm guessing I may have had on crooked or something and blew this bad boy out.  I'll try a new cable and refurbish it with a new LCD.  Otherwise, this bad boy is working now - SOLVED : )
